text:
Raskolnikov stood at the corner of the Hay Market. 

“I like it on cold, dark, damp autumn evenings,” he said. 

A stranger glanced nervously. 

“I don’t know… Excuse me…” he muttered, crossing the street. 

Raskolnikov continued, spotting a young man in a red shirt. 

“Isn’t there a man with a booth here?” 

“All sorts of people keep booths,” the young man replied, unimpressed. 

“What’s his name?” 

“What he was christened,” came the dismissive answer. 

“Are you a Zaraïsky man, too?” 

“It’s a district, your excellency,” he sneered. 

“Is that a tavern up there?” 

“Yes, an eating-house. You’ll find princesses there too.” 

Raskolnikov crossed the square, lost in thought.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on his surroundings and engages in a brief, awkward conversation with a stranger while searching for familiar faces in a marketplace.
